quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: This is a Bill for the appropriation of £262,415, to cover the services for the following month. The amount on this occasion is smaller than it was on the last occasion. The Bill contains no unusual items. Under the head of " Military " there is an item of £3,300, which is a portion of the amount for the Easter encampment which will be held. I am authorized by the Minister for Defence to say that he has had under consideration the cessation of recruiting, that he will complete his consideration of the subject at a very early period, probably some time next, week, and that lie is disposed to allow recruiting to go on up to the present strength. He finds that, on the whole, it is better that that should be done. There is nothing, I think, in the other items which call for comment although I shall be glad to answer any questions which may be asked. As it is intended to adjourn the Senate over Easter, it is necessary to pass the Bill to-day in order that the public creditors and the public officers may be paid.

I thank the Vice-President of the Executive Council for the statement he has made in reference to the recruiting to fill vacancies in the citizens branch of the military forces, in respect of which I asked some questions the other day. With a view to assist the Minister, I desire very briefly to state what the facts are. We know, of course, that time permanent forces are being recruited. The other recruiting which has been referred to means not the taking on of one extra man throughout any portion of the Commonwealth, but merely filling existing vacancies, which are sufficiently numerous, owing to the cessation of recruiting for about six months, to materially interfere with the efficiency of the defence forces in the different States. I am not referring to one State more than another. This matter is affecting the discipline, and certainly the morale, of the forces to a very large extent. Alen have felt that they were surrounded by difficulties and impending difficulties, which causes them to lose heart in the discharge of the either unpaid or very little paid duties, as the case may be, in the volunteer and militia forces. The statement of the Minister that this unsatisfactory state of things is likely to be ended will be a matter or very great gladness to all who take an interest in the citizen forces. The fact that the forces are to be asked to go into camp to improve their training will be a cause of satisfaction, I admit, to every taxpayer, because it is of no use to have an undisciplined mob, and call it a defence force. The statement of the Minister is satisfactory, and I hope that the Ministerial consideration will be given promptly. If there is any further delay in the filling of vacancies, the recruits taken on cannot be trained and passed into the ranks before the dote of the financial year ending 30th June. If they are not passed into the ranks, there is riot a regiment in the Commonwealth that will be able to draw its full capitation allowance, by virtue of which the men are clothed. The recruits cannot be properly trained in less than three months, and if they are not passed into the ranks as efficient members of the force by that date, the regiments will lose their capitation allowance under the existing regulations in respect of every absent man. Then, if you take the recruits on at the beginning of next year you will be short of so much money to clothe them, and the force will be materially damaged for the whole twelve months. That is why I would impress on Senator O'Connor that there should be no time lost in the Ministerial consideration and the revoking of the ukase that went out last year as to the filling of vacancies. I could give abundance of instances in addition to reasons why this is desirable, but in the circumstances I trust that the Ministerial assurance will have prompt effect given to it.

The act of the Ministers and their supporters in the Senate has deprived honourable senators of an opportunity to discuss private business on private member's day, and I take advantage of this opportunity to say a word or two on that question. I wish to ask Senator O'Connor whether he has any idea that the session is likely to be concluded this year I We have been sitting for nearly twelve months. It is proposed, as soon as this Bill is passed, to have a short adjournment. It has been understood since the Electoral Bill was introduced that a short adjournment would be made in order to allow Senator O'Connor and his colleague to make some preparation for the great work which they will have to do during the next few weeks. I suppose we cannot object to that.

According to the strict construction of the standing orders no question can be debated on the second reading of a Supply Bill or Appropriation Bill which is not relevant to its subject matter, but inasmuch as the Senate does not go into Committee of Supply, and it has no other opportunity of airing grievances, I propose to allow Senator Higgs to continue his remarks unless the Senate objects.

The statement of my grievance is not likely to be a lengthy one. Ministers took away private members’ day some months ago, in order that they might rush through the business of the session. It was understood that if private members would consent to give up their day to the discussion of public business, we should get through the work much sooner, but the use of that day his not helped the Government very much. if the session is likely to last until the end of the year, Ministers ought to restore to private members their day, in order that we might discuss matters which affect ourselves or our States. We have no opportunity of discussing such matters, unless we move the adjournment of the Senate--a course which, as a rule, no one cares to take. If it is proposed to continue the session for two or three months, Ministers ought to give us at least two or three hours each week to discuss private members' business.

I entirely disagree with Senator Riggs with regard to the value of private members' business. I have had considerable experience in connexion with private members' business. A great portion of it is of the most useless character. Let us take the private members' business on the notice-paper and see how time would be employed in discussing it—certainly not profitably. First of all we find this motion in the name of Senator Stewart—

quote.para: That, in the opinion of this Senate the suppression of public meetings in Ireland, at a tune when that country is practically free from crime of an agrarian character, and more especially at this most critical period in the Empire's history, when every endeavour should be made to cement all sections and denominations in a union of hearts, is not only a serious invasion of the free speech which is the birthright of every Briton, but is highly detrimental to the best interests of the British people.

speech.para: What on earth is the good of discussing such matters?

talk.start.para: The honourable senator must not anticipate the discussion on the notice of motion.

I can imagine that if the Senate were to pass a motion which referred to some distant part of the world its people might very properly say. — "Please, good Australians, mind your own business, and do not interfere with the business of other people." Next we have this notice of motion, in the name of Senator Pearce—

quote.para: That, in the opinion of the Senate, in order to provide a fund for the payment of old age pensions, and for other purposes, it is desirable that the manufacture and sale of tobacco, cigars, and cigarettes should become a national monopoly within the Commonwealth.

continue.para: My experience of private members business —and it has been a very long one —is that, with the exception of a few motions now and then, it means a perfect waste of the time of Parliament. There are occasions, of course, when very valuable motions are moved under that head, but in the great majority of instances the time of honourable members is frittered away in academical discussions, only fit for some small debating society in the back blocks. I quite appreciate the action of the Government in taking to itself the whole of the time of the Senate, seeing that we can more usefully be employed upon questions that must be settled, and which are of vital importance to the community. I certainly disagree with my honourable friend Senator Higgs. Unless we have more important questions upon the notice-paper to be brought up by private members, I hope the Government will monopolize the whole of the time at our disposal in future.

talk.start.para: I wish to draw attention in the first place to Part VIII. of the schedule to the Bill. It consists of votes for the Postmaster-General's department. I particularly wish to direct attention to the absolute want of uniformity that characterizes the provisions with regard to the different States. Under the last heading, Division No. 136, "Expenditure in the state of Tasmania," there are three sub-divisions—No. 1, salaries; No. 2, contingencies and No. 3, conveyance of mails. In the case of New South Wales the subdivisions are the same. But in other cases, such as that of South Australia, we simply have salaries and contingencies, and we do not know what are the provisions made with regard to the carrying of mails. In regard to Western Australia there are three subdivisions salaries, fixed allowance, and contingencies; and there is no subdivision whatever with reference to the carriage of mails. I would also point out to the Postmaster-General that the people in the north-western, northern, and western parts of Tasmania are suffering considerable inconvenience by reason of the fact that the English mails to Tasmania are made up for the older established centres of population like Hobart and Launceston. So far as the Inter-State mails are concerned, the grievance has been rectified to some extent. A boat will go from Melbourne to Burnie, carrying the English mails. After they are lauded at. Burnie, they are taken on to Launceston, a six hours' railway journey, and then they are sorted and sent back to Burnie, often causing a delay or 36 hours. From that place they are sent on to the West Coast, causing a delay in the case of those letters of from 48 to 60 hours. That delay would be prevented if there were mail bags made up for the separate places, or if there were a sorting room on board the boat. I think the State of Tasmania is entitled to have a sorting room, just as there are such rooms on the mail trains travelling between the States of the mainland. There is also another matter in connexion with the Postal department to which I wish to allude. I would earnestly direct the attention of honourable senators and of the Postmaster-General to it. I had intended to take another opportunity of alluding to this matter, but now that I am dealing with the administration of the Postal department, I would invite earnest attention to the subject in order that the legislation which we have passed after much deliberation, and which we now all accept, no matter how we may have opposed it individually when it was submitted to us, may be administered in a fair and equitable manner. I asked the Postmaster-General this morning a question with regard to the administration of section 57 of the Post and Telegraph Act. As the Senate had by that time entered upon the business of the clay it was not competent for me to take exception to his reply. The question I asked the honourable gentleman was whether—

quote.para: He will, without delay, in pursuance of the powers conferred on him by section 57 of the Post and Telegraph Act 1901, interdict the transmission through the Poet-office of correspondence addressed to persons carrying on business as bookmakers, turf tipsters, or turf commission agents, and if not, 'why not.

speech.para: To that the honourable and learned senator replied that he—

quote.para: is not aware nor has he been officially advised of the transmission through the Post office of correspondence in contravention of the section referred to, except in a few instances, and in those action has been taken.

speech.para: It is not necessary for me to enter upon any discussion as to the position of Tasmania from a revenue point of view or from any other aspect with reference to the action that has been taken by the Government to induce the Commonwealth Government to withhold their hand in connexion with the prohibition of the transmission of the correspondence to "Tattersall’s." We all know the circumstances of the case, and I have no intention of dwelling upon them. But I would remind honourable senators that, after considerable discussion, both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament passed that particular section of the Post and Telegraph Act which empowers the Postmaster-General to stop the transmission of correspondence to a person if he be satisfied that that person is receiving, either in the Commonwealth or elsewhere—

quote.para: Money or any other valuable thing as consideration (1) for an assurance or agreement expressed or implied to pay or give or (2) for securing that some other person shall pay or give any money or valuable thing on an event or contingency of or relating to any horse race or other race, or any fight, game, sport, or exercise; (b) for promoting or carrying out a scheme connected with any such assurance, agreement, or security or a lottery or scheme of chance, or an unlawful game; or (c) as contributions or subscriptions towards any lottery or scheme of chance.

speech.para: The Postmaster-General tells me this morning that he "is not aware, nor has he been officially advised," that correspondence is going through the post in contravention of that section of the Act. I have taken the last issue of a newspaper that is published in Melbourne, called the Sportsman. The number of the paper is 1099, and it is issued weekly; showing that it has been in existence over twenty years. On the very first page of that paper I find advertisement after advertisement by bookmakers, turf commission agents, and turf tipsters inviting the public to use the Post-office for sending them money in return for which they will give their clients starting prices on various events. Let honourable senators take this morning's Argus. They will find there the advertisement of a man named Heatley. This is not a single case. Such instances are occurring day after day in connexion with every race meeting. Can the Postmaster-General seriously say to this Senate and to the people of Australia, "You have legislated through the Parliament of the Commonwealth in the direction of not allowing the Post-office to be used for the conveyance of communications respecting gambling, and I have interdicted the transmission of correspondence to a certain limited extent”; whilst here we have examples in one issue of this newspaper—and such examples arc occurring day after day and week after week--advertising the fact that the Post-office is repeatedly used in contravention of the Act? There are in the paper I hold in my hand advertisements of this character and which I will quote. One is from—

quote.para: Fred W. Norman (late Jack Cohen), Bowes' Tattersall's Club, Melbourne.

speech.para: Then follows a list of racing events, after which comes the notification—

quote.para: Letters and telegrams answered immediately on receipt. No reply, no business. S.P. S.P. S.P.

speech.para: Those letters meaning, I presume, starting prices. Then we have the advertisement of—

quote.para: Sol Green, Tattersall's Club, 224 Bourke-street, Melbourne; Tattersall's Club, Sydney; Tattersall's Club, Adelaide . . . . S.P., straight out and doubles . . . . Only Victorian address: Sol Green, Tattersall's Club. All correspondence receives immediate attention. All telegrams must be reply paid, otherwise they will he answered by post.

speech.para: Then we have-

quote.para: Alfred Vockler, premier turf adviser.

speech.para: This advertisement illustrates some of the inducements which are held out to the public to use the Post-office to further the gambling propensities with which many in this country are afflicted.

quote.para: For Ballarat, Thursday and Friday, reliable, exclusive, and valuable information. At this last meeting last year I put up the phenomenal record of ten winners out of twelve events. On the second day I selected every winner on the card. Further comment on this performance would be "painting the lily."

speech.para: He, Vockler, is "the lily!" Here are these men deliberately inviting the public to use the Post-office to send their money and get starting prices and tips on these various events. He goes on—

quote.para: Fees, 10s, daily; £2 monthly. Doubles, 15s. Telegrams must be reply paid. Address, 1 Maritime Chambers, Swanston-street. Private address, Medlock House, 71 Rathdown-street, opposite Exhibition Gardens.

speech.para: These advertisements are all on the front page of the Sportsman, and I simply take this as one of many similar papers. Indeed, the Postmaster-General can find such advertisements in the Argus of to-day and yesterday.

talk.start.para: Would the honourable and learned senator mind informing me again where ten winners out of twelve are to be obtained?
That is in the advertisement of Vockler
Thank you. The honourable and learned senator is leading me astray!
Here is another—

quote.para: The Count (late H. Oxenham and The Count), commission agent, Victorian Club, Melbourne. The Count is a member of the Victorian Club, Melbourne; Tattersall Club, Sydney; and Tattersall's Club, Adelaide. The Count may be see the club. Telegrams should be reply paid. No reply nobusiness. Longest odds guaranteed S.P. on all Sydney events.

continue.para: I could multiply these instances practically ad infinitum. But what I particularly wish to draw attention to is the fact that the Postmaster-General has directed my notice to one or two instances in which he says lie has used the powers conferred upon him by the Post and Telegraph Act, to interdict the use of the Post-office by persons carrying on this business. All he can show me that he has done, however, is that he has interdicted the correspondence of the following:—

quote.para: Phillip Anderson, 411 Campbell-street., Newtown, Sydney. “Old Trainer," Moonee Ponds.

continue.para: How did the Postmaster-General get to know that those particular persons were carrying on business through the Post-office? Did he get to know through his officials? If so, how did they get to know it except through the correspondence? Why does not the Postmaster-General take further action, and interdict the correspondence of others of these men who are "cursing" Australia, are inducing people to send money to them, and using the Post-office to get small amounts into their bags? It is a pure farce to say that this Act is being administered in a fair and equitable manner and in the way in which Parliament has a right to expect the Government to administer it—that is to say, in the manner in which the Senate and the House of Representatives intended it to be administered when the legislation was passed. I wish it to be understood distinctly that I am taking no exception to the legislation in question. We have passed it, and the time for debate as to its expediency has gone by. But so long as I am a member of this Senate, I shall use my utmost endeavours to see that the Act is enforced. It ought not to be on the statute book, as a mere piece of paper with printing on it, which has no meaning whatever. Is it not to be enforced unless the Postmaster-General is induced to enforce it by a deputation of interested persons—interested, I mean, on grounds which commend themselves to them? What does the Postmaster-General mean by saying that he has "no official intimation" of the existence of individuals like those who are carrying on business as tipsters and commission agents in Melbourne and elsewhere? He says that he—

quote.para: [is not aware, nor has he been officially advised, of the transmission through the Post-office of correspondence in contravention of the section referred to.

continue.para: Does the Postmaster-General mean to say by "officially advised "that he intends to wait for a deputation from the National Citizens Temperance League or some other organization before he will put the Act into operation? If it is determined that lie is not to exercise these powers until waited upon under any circumstances, I can promise that I shall organize a deputation to wait upon him, and to bring under his attention the fact that there are in various parts of this Commonwealth men carrying on a business which is aimed at by the very legislation we have passed, and who are receiving such communications through the post under his very eyes. Let us have one law all round—one sauce for the goose, and one for the gander. I take particular notice of this matter for the simple reason that, as honourable senators know, there has been a considerable amount of feeling engendered in the State from which I come. Rightly or wrongly, the matter is there looked upon as one of State rights. It is regarded as an unwarrantable interference with State rights and interests, and as conflicting with the domestic and social legislation of Tasmania, that Tattersall's "correspondence should have been interdicted by the Postmaster-Genera]. I do not say whether the Tasmanian people who take exception to the law are right or wrong in that respect, but I do say distinctly that the action of the Postmaster-General in singling out that one particular instance for the exercise of these powers, and ignoring all those other glaring instances which must be under his notice, and must be under the constant notice of the officers of his department, can only accentuate the irritation that is felt throughout the State from which I come. The Postmaster-General or his subordinates, in discriminating in this way without any justification whatever, have been to my mind shamefully neglectful of the duty cast upon them by the Act. I hope that the Postmaster General will recognise in the future that this is not a matter to be trifled With. The legislation is there upon the statute-book. The object of it, and the arguments adduced by those who favoured it, were that we were not going to allow our postal department to be used as an engine for the promotion of gambling. The Postmaster-General is permitting that every day in the instances I have quoted, and in many more. Until we see the names of Sol. Green, the Count, Fred. W. Norman, Alfred Vockler, and others who are carrying on this "pernicious occupation " in Australia placed upon the interdicted list by the Post-master-General, he himself and his department will stand condemned in the eyes of every fair minded and right-thinking person in this community, no matter what may be their views upon the subject of gambling.

talk.start.para: The honourable and learned senator might have brought this matter on at some other time. He could have moved the adjournment.

I had no other opportunity. The Postmaster-General, in answer to the question I submitted to him this morning, made what I consider to be an evasive reply. He showed that his eyes have been closed to what has been going on around him. It was incompetent for me then to move the adjournment of the Senate, as the business of the day had been called on, and had to be called on for ray question to be put, but, as I understand that when we rise to-day we shall adjourn for a considerable time, and as the 31st March will have gone by—the date from which commences the interdiction of the correspondence to Tattersall – before we meet again, I felt bound to take this opportunity of calling attention to the administration of the Act. I say unhesitatingly to the Postmaster-General, and the members of the Cabinet to which he belongs, that if they persist in the administration of the provisions of the Act to which I refer in the present absolutely unfair manner, and if they do not administer it honestly all round, as was intended to be done when it was incorporated in the legislation of the Commonwealth, they will lose the confidence of a great ninny honourable senators in this Chamber and in the House of Representatives, and will have shown that they are absolutely weak-knead in carrying out legislation which they asked us to pass, and that a spirit of unfairness characterizes their action in connexion with that legislation.

The honourable and learned senator has complained in the first place of the way in which these estimates are framed. I wish to tell him again, as I told him on the last occasion when a Supply Bill was before us, that the headings in relation to each department must be read in connexion with the estimates for the year. Those estimates have been laid upon the table of the House of Representatives, and have been circulated for the information of Members of Parliament. They are framed in a certain form, following the form adopted in the States in the past. The headings in this Bill correspond with the headings in the estimates. I have said already that, when the time comes for preparing new estimates, I shall endeavour to arrange so that the amounts will be given in greater detail than is the case here. Seeing that these amounts refer in each case to the amounts upon the estimates, the only course that we can follow is to adopt the same headings. That is why in the ease of one State the amount may appear under the heading of "contingencies," while in the case of another it is split up under "contingencies," "mail services," and, perhaps, other headings. I am glad that Senator Keating admits that we have carried out his wishes with regard to the Inter-State mails. So far as the English mails are concerned, we have asked the Imperial authorities time after time to sort the mails and send them out in separate bags, so as to facilitate their distribution at this end.
Does the department sort the English mails on board the steamers between here and Tasmania?

We desire to give every facility in regard to mail services, but we have to consider whether the necessities of the case are sufficient to warrant the expense of employing a special officer to sort the English mails during their transit from Melbourne to Tasmania. With regard to that celebrated provision, section 57 of the Postal Act, I do not think that Senator Keating has made out any case against my department. It is refreshing to find him here in quite a new character. When that provision was last before the Senate, I understood him to be entirely against it; he did not believe in letters being stopped. Now we find that the clause having been passed, the honourable and learned senator is in favour of stopping some letters which have not been stopped hitherto. That is to say that, because his particular friends suffer a grievance, someone else's friends are to suffer the same grievance in order to satisfy him. What have we done? Tho two cases mentioned by Senator Keating were cases in which action was taken by the department before the Postal Bill was assented to. In the one case the person involved was a tipster. In both instances information was first obtained from an officer in the department. We then applied to the police, and received information from them in regard to the operations of these persons. It was upon that information that the letters were stopped. Since the Postal Act has come into operation notice has been given to three different persons that their letters will be stopped. One is "Tattersall"; another is a man whose name, is 'Jarmulowsky"; while the other is a man with a name still more unpronounceable.
Why do you not stop Oxenham's letters?

Every case that is properly brought before the department as one in which persons are carrying on the business aimed at in section 57, will be inquired into in the same way. There have been no other cases brought under my notice, since the five to which I have referred.
If the Minister is to wait to be moved from outside in these matters, he will have to be moved himself.
Every case will receive the same consideration. If Senator Keating likes to introduce a deputation to me, it will receive, the same courteous treatment that other deputations have received.
What further notice does the department require than that given by the fact that these letters are going through their hands?
Or the advertisements in the newspapers?
It is not the duty of the Postmaster-General to read the advertisements, nor do I conceive it to be the duty of any of my officers to do so.
The Postmaster-General desires administration by deputation.

That is not so, It is necessary first of all to show the department that someone is carrying, on business in an improper way, and that the power given in the section referred to should be put into effect.
It is fortunate that the Customs department is not carried on in that way.
That is a very different matter. The Customs department employs officers who might almost be termed detectives, in order to see that the revenue is not defrauded.
So does the Postal department
Does not the Minister intend to act on the information just brought before him by Senator Keating?

I am not prepared to say now whether any one of those cases come properly within section 57. In every case where it has been brought under my notice that the Post-office is being used for purposes which appear to be contrary to the provisions of that section, I have caused some inquiries to be made in order to satisfy me whether the section is being contravened, and that is the course I propose to take in the future.
Before the Bill goes into committee, I desire to intimate, that if nothing be done in the meantime, I intend to test the feeling of the. Senate by taking another course when we re-assemble.

speech.para: In Committee-
Clauses 1, 2 and 3 agreed to.
The schedule-

talk.start.para: When the last Supply Bill was before the committee, it was stated, in answer to a question by Senator Stewart, that General Hutton's travelling allowances would be paid by the Government, and that the Ministry were considering the question of paying the travelling allowances of his staff. I would like to ask if any provision is made for such payments in the vote for defence?

Yes. "Contingencies,” under the heading of "Headquarters Staff," include travelling allowances for General Hutton and a portion of his staff. Honourable senators will recognise that if General Hutton is to carry out his work, he must have his staff with him, and that the members of that staff cannot be expected to pay their own travelling expenses.

At this late hoe there is no time to raise an objection to the vote, but I wish to enter my protest against any payment for travelling allowances being made to General Hutton's staff. Having in view the nature of his duties, and the hurried character of the visits paid recently by him to other States, I consider that there was no necessity for him to take his staff with him oil those occasions.

continue.para: Bill reported, with amendment, and passed through its remaining stages

talk.start.para: I Move—

speech.para: That the Senate at its rising adjourn until Thursday, 3rd April.
That will enable honourable senators to have some little time to themselves before Easter as well as the Easter holidays

talk.start.para: Why should we meet until the following week?

I have consulted the Prime Minister as to the condition of business in the other House, and it appears to me that it would be unsafe to adjourn beyond the 3rd of April, having regard to the business that we have to do. We have to dispose of the Public Service Bill, and I hope that we shall receive the Tariff in the following week. I do not agree with Senator Play ford's views in regard to private members' business. I consider that private members are entitled to have some consideration, and I can only again express my thanks for the consideration they have shown for the interests of the public in allowing public business to take precedence over private members' business. I shall ask them to continue that consideration until we have disposed of the Tariff, unless, before we receive it, there is no other urgent business to be dealt with. I am sure that I can rely on the public spirit of honourable senators who have private business on the notice paper to allow urgent public matters to take precedence. Subject to that condition I have every desire to facilitate private members' business.

It seems to me that we should meet on Wednesday, 2nd April, instead of on the following day, otherwise we may have some honourable senators saving that Ave, should not meet until the following week. I would ask Senator O'Connor to suggest to his colleagues that the tariff should leave another place before the Easter adjournment, even if late sittings are necessary to secure that end. We have a right to consider now when we are going to get back to our homes and our businesses. Unless we receive the Tariff within the next few days we shall be here until July. I the Tariff were disposed of by another place before Easter, necessary papers might be in readiness to assist us on our re-assembling.

I am sure that every honourable senator is as desirous as is the Vice-President of the Executive Council of giving whatever attendance is necessary in order to carry on public business satisfactorily. But I think that he will agree with me that an effort should be made to bestow the maximum convenience upon the maximum number of members. It is proposed that we should meet two days in one week and three in the following week. If, instead of sitting five days in two weeks, we were to take the five days in one, it would be a great convenience to those who are able to return to their homes at the end of each 'week. I have very grave doubts whether the Tariff can be here on the week after we reassemble, and even if it is I do not think it will be considered unreasonable if after Senator O'Connor's second speech is made, a short adjournment takes place. I, for one, do not know exactly what effect the alterations made by the other House will have upon the Tariff, and I desire to hear a statement on the subject from the Vice-President of the Executive Council. If my view is correct, we shall be in exactly the same position about the 12th of next month, whether we carry out Senator O'Connor's programme or that suggested by me. While on the other hand, if he can see his way to adopt my suggestion it will avoid one trip from Sydney or Hobart or Adelaide. Although he has said that he can hardly fall in with the suggestion offered by Senator Gould, I ask him to reconsider it, seeing that there can be no possible loss of the time which the Senate is prepared to place at t the disposal of the Government.

I am inclined to agree with the remarks of Senator Millen. In common with the rest of us, Senator O’Connor feels the great desirability of securing a proper discussion on the amendments to the public service Bill. If we meet on the Thursday in that week there will be certainly be a thin House. I am quite prepared to attend on that day, but I am convinced that we shall have a very poor House indeed to discuss the amendment in that Bill. If Senator O’Connor can give us assurance-and I think it will meet the convenience of a majority-that Thursday and Friday will be taken for the consideration of private members’ business, I shall not quite oppose the motion. But on the other hand, as an alternative, I am prepared, and I believe every honourable senator would be prepared, to come on Tuesday in the following week.

I should be very glad, indeed, if I could give effect to the suggestions winch have been made, but, as has been shown, honourable senators have differing views as to what convenience is, and I have to take the responsibility of proposing the course which is most convenient to the House and to the conduct of public business. I have consulted the Prime Minister as to the probable date at which the Tariff will reach this House. We do not wish to adjourn the Senate for such a period as would perhaps give an intimation to another place that there was no necessity to hurry on the completion of the Tariff. We desire to have the Tariff brought here as quickly as possible, and there can be no stronger efforts made than those which have been made by the Government to expedite its arrival. I recognise the force of what Senator Clemons has said about the consideration of the amendments in the Public Service Bill. If honourable senators are not here to go on with the business, then it will have to be done by those who are here.
It is a very inconvenient day.

I am quite aware of that; but on the other hand we have to consider the convenience of it number of honourable senators who are always here ready to do the business. Besides that, there is private business to go on with – some of it great importance-which ought to be considered.
Will the Minister consent to go on with private members' business?

It is impossible for me to say now that I shall not go on with the Public Service Bill on the Thursday. I am ready to proceed with the Government business whenever it comes on. I do not say that it will come, but so far as I can, I shall see that it comes on as usual on the Thursday. I am sorry that I cannot meet the convenience of everyone, but the course I am taking is, I think, the best in the public interest.
